awd_titl_txt: Optimizing Vaccination Incentives to Prevent Disease Outbreaks
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the advancement of the national health and welfare by designing effective mechanisms to improve the vaccination rate for communicable diseases. Vaccination is one of the most effective public health interventions to prevent, control, and eliminate disease. The objective of this research is to identify optimal vaccination incentives given resource constraints to prevent disease outbreaks in a population.  Barriers to high vaccination coverage include vaccine shortages, cost, lack of universal vaccination records, complexity of adherence, misinformation, and personal and cultural beliefs.  This research will have broad impact on millions of individuals by providing policy makers with tools to promote vaccination uptake through sequential intervention design and effective utilization of healthcare resources to improve population health.  The interdisciplinary nature of this research will provide students with diversified education and training.

The PIs will develop an integrated modeling framework that combines incentive mechanism design via a game-theoretic approach, social network influencer identification, and agent-based simulation of large population infection networks. The research will advance multi-fidelity simulation optimization methods and apply them to optimize vaccination incentive policies to achieve herd immunity using the agent-based simulation. Incentives may include financial rewards to all individuals seeking vaccination, cost sharing for medical care, and/or incentives to social influencers via education outreach. Urban and rural use-cases will be analyzed to provide insights into controlling and eliminating the measles in the U.S. Going beyond the U.S. setting, the modeling framework can be generalized to low- and middle-income countries.  The team will disseminate results from this work through publications in top journals, conferences across disciplines, and targeted public health agencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
This research contributes to the advancement of national health and welfare with the creation of infectious disease models that provide valuable insights to policymakers on effective non-pharmaceutical interventions to manage the spread of the disease.  The COVID-19 pandemic has posed unprecedented challenges, and we developed a large-scale agent-based simulation to evaluate public health interventions, including mask wearing and social distancing, for COVID-19 pandemic scenarios in a large urban area (King County, WA).  As viruses keep mutating and vaccines lose effectiveness, we addressed the question of how often to update vaccines and when can the public safely relax interventions. To address vaccine hesitancy, we developed a compartmental model that couples opinion behavior dynamics with disease transmission. To promote vaccination uptake, we identify optimal resource allocation to vaccine promotion campaigns targeting different age and geographic groups.

In creating infectious disease models, it is important to calibrate parameters so that the model outputs align with observed data. However, it is necessary to recognize uncertainties, not only in the model but also in the target data, in order to understand the impact and variability of future scenarios.  We introduce “representative calibration” that acknowledges uncertainties and provides statistical interpretations of recommended policy actions.

This research provides policy makers with tools to promote vaccination uptake and recommend interventions to improve population health, with potential impact on millions of individuals.  The interdisciplinary nature of this research, including epidemiologists and public health researchers, provides students with diversified education and training.  The team is disseminating results from this work through publications in top journals, conferences across disciplines, and targeted public health agencies.

 


Last Modified: 03/25/2024
Modified by: Zelda B Zabinsky
